meanings.def: resting on the surface of somebody/something and partly or completely covering them/it
examples: She put a blanket over the sleeping child.
He wore an overcoat over his suit.
She put her hand over her mouth to stop herself from screaming.

meanings.def: in or to a position higher than but not touching somebody/something; above somebody/something
examples: They held a large umbrella over her.
The balcony juts out over the street.
There was a lamp hanging over the table.

meanings.def: from one side of something to the other; across something
examples: a bridge over the river
They ran over the grass.
They had a wonderful view over the park.

meanings.def: so as to cross something and be on the other side
examples: She climbed over the wall.

meanings.def: falling from or down from a place
examples: The car had toppled over the cliff.
He didn't dare look over the edge.

meanings.def: on the far or opposite side of something
examples: He lives over the road.

meanings.def: in or on all or most parts of something
examples: Snow is falling all over the country.
They've travelled all over the world.
There were papers lying around all over the place.

meanings.def: more than a particular time, amount, cost, etc.
examples: over 3 million copies sold
She stayed in Lagos for over a month.
He's over sixty.

meanings.def: used to show that somebody has control or authority
examples: She has only the director over her.
He ruled over a great empire.
She has editorial control over what is included.

meanings.def: during something
examples: We'll discuss it over lunch.
Over the next few days they got to know the town well.
She has not changed much over the years.
He built up the business over a period of ten years.
We're away over (= until after) the New Year.

meanings.def: past a particular difficult stage or situation
examples: We're over the worst of the recession.
It took her ages to get over her illness.

meanings.def: because of or relating to something; about something
examples: an argument over money
a disagreement over the best way to proceed

meanings.def: using something; by means of something
examples: We heard it over the radio.
She wouldn't tell me over the phone.

meanings.def: louder than something
examples: I couldn't hear what he said over the noise of the traffic.

meanings.def: in addition to something
examples: There are other factors over and above those we have discussed.
There are other factors over and above those we have discussed.
They built a new room above/​over the garage.
They jumped over the stream.
He put a blanket over the sleeping child.
2 000 feet above sea level
Temperatures will not rise above zero tonight.
He’s over 50.
It costs over £100.
We waited over 2 hours.

meanings.def: across a street, an open space, etc.
examples: I stopped and crossed over.
He rowed us over to the other side of the lake.
They have gone over to France.
This is my aunt who's over from Canada.
I went over (= across the room) and asked her name.
Put it down over there.

meanings.def: downwards and away from the correct position standing upright
examples: Try not to knock that vase over.
The wind must have blown it over.

meanings.def: from one side to another side
examples: She turned over onto her front.
The car skidded off the road and rolled over and over.

meanings.def: so as to cover somebody/something completely
examples: The lake was frozen over.
Cover her over with a blanket.

meanings.def: above; more
examples: children of 14 and over
You get an A grade for scores of 75 and over.

meanings.def: not used or needed
examples: If there's any food left over, put it in the fridge.

meanings.def: ended
examples: By the time we arrived the meeting was over.
Thank goodness that's over!
I was glad when it was over and done with.

meanings.def: again
examples: He repeated it several times over until he could remember it.
(North American English) It's all wrong—you'll have to do it over.

meanings.def: used to talk about somebody/something changing position
examples: He's gone over to the enemy (= joined them).
Please change the wheels over (= for example, put the front wheels at the back).
Let's ask some friends over (= to our home).
Hand over the money!

meanings.def: used when communicating by radio
examples: Message received. Over (= it is your turn to speak).
Message understood. Over and out.

meanings.def: a second time from the beginning
examples: He did the work so badly that I had to do it all over again myself.

meanings.def: in contrast with something
many times; repeatedly
examples: I've told you over and over again not to do that.

meanings.def: used to say that it is somebody’s turn to do something

idioms.def: a second time from the beginning
examples: He did the work so badly that I had to do it all over again myself.
I've told you over and over again not to do that.

idioms.def: used to say that it is somebody’s turn to do something

meanings.def: a series of six balls bowled by the same person
examples: Chadwick dismissed two batsmen in the same over.

meanings.def: more than usual; too much
examples: overproduction
overload
over-optimistic
overconfident
overanxious

meanings.def: completely
examples: overjoyed

meanings.def: upper; outer; extra
examples: overcoat
overtime

meanings.def: over; above
examples: overcast
overhang
